document.docAuthor: Soares, Karla D. A., Gomes, Ulisses L. & De Carvalho, Marcelo R.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of catsharks of the Scyliorhinus haeckelii group, with the description of a new species (Chondrichthyes: Carcharhiniformes: Scyliorhinidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of catsharks of the Scyliorhinus haeckelii group, with the description of a new species (Chondrichthyes: Carcharhiniformes: Scyliorhinidae)

bibRefCitation.author: Miranda
bibRefCitation.refString: Miranda Ribeiro, A. M. (1907) Fauna braziliense. Peixes II (Desmobranchios). Archivos do Museu Nacional, 14, 2 - 20.

subSubSection.paragraph: Common names: freckled catshark, polkadot catshark, caÃ§Ã£o-pinto.

Catulus haeckelii
Miranda Ribeiro, 1907
, pp. 163â165 , fig. 8 (original description, figured).
Scyliorhinus boa :
Bigelow & Schroeder, 1948
, pp. 204â207 , fig. 32 (photograph of holotype of
S. haeckelii
included in species account).

Scyliorhinus fernandezi

, pp. 3â7 , fig. 1 (original description).

Scyliorhinus retifer haeckelii :
Springer & Sadowsky, 1970
, pp. 92â93 (description).

Scyliorhinus retifer besnardi
Springer & Sadowsky, 1970
, pp. 94â97 , fig. 2 (described as a new subspecies, figured). [New synonymy]

Scyliorhinus retifer :

, p. 13 , fig. 16 (general account, illustrated).

Scyliorhinus haeckeli :

, pp. 362â363 (general account, illustrated).

Scyliorhinus haeckelii / besnardi
group
Gadig, 2003
, pp. 147â148 (compilation);
Gomes et al., 2010
, pp. 84â85 , fig. 109 (brief account, illustrated);
Soares, 2014
, pp. 71â79 , figs. 2, 10, 15, 16, 56 (revision, illustrated);
Soares et al ., 2015
, p. 1 (compared to
S. ugoi
, described as new).

Holotype
. MNRJ 494 , immature male, 316 mm TL ( Ilha Rasa, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil ).

Additional material examined .
124 specimens
(see Appendix). Specimens cited by
Springer & Sadowsky ( 1970 )
, including the paratypes of
Scyliorhinus retifer besnardi
, originally part of the Instituto OceanogrÃ¡fico of Universidade de SÃ£o Paulo, were not found and are presumed lost.

Diagnosis . A species of
Scyliorhinus
from the southwestern Atlantic distinguished by having a triangular or squared tipped first dorsal fin ( vs. first dorsal fin never squared tipped in
S. ugoi
and
S. cabofriensis
), neurocranium with a narrow basal plate ( vs. broad basal plate in
S. cabofriensis
), color pattern with saddles not delineated by light or dark spots ( vs . saddles delineated by light or dark spots in
S. boa
), saddles darker than background color and lacking sharp median projections ( vs . saddles indistinct in
S. cabofriensis
and
S. boa
and with sharp median projections in
S. ugoi
), and spots large and small, sometimes sickle-shaped or lunate and with clear centers on the back and sides, arranged in approximate bilateral symmetry, and sometimes present in intersaddle regions ( vs. spots spiracle-sized, randomly distributed, not sickle-shaped or lunate in
S. cabofriensis
). The following combination of characters, although less conspicuous, also distinguishes these species: snout rounded and short, preoral length 4.5 % TL ( vs. 5 % TL in
S. ugoi
and in
S. cabofriensis
); head short and depressed, its length 17.5â19.2 % TL ( vs. 19.7â20.8 % in
S. cabofriensis
and 19.5â20.3 % in
S. ugoi
); interdorsal space 1.2â2 times dorsal-caudal space ( vs. 2 times in
S. cabofriensis
and 2.1â2.5 in
S. ugoi
); claspers with ventral terminal cartilage 2 slender and positioned above ventral terminal cartilage, its length 1.8 times in ventral terminal cartilage ( vs . 1.5 times in
S. cabofriensis
); ventral terminal cartilage without a prominent groove posteriorly or with shallow and poorly developed groove ( vs . groove well developed in
S. cabofriensis
); small-sized, adult males at about 353 mm TL and adult females at about 415 mm TL ( vs . 445 mm and 500 mm TL, respectively, in
S. ugoi
).

Description . Morphometric data are given in
Table 1
and neurocranial measurements in
Table 6
. Modes of meristic counts are given, as well as their range, in parentheses, when values differ.

Teeth morphologically similar in both jaws; tooth row counts 52 / 49 ( 48â54 / 43â53 ), in 3 / 3 ( 2â3 / 2â3 ) functional series (
Tab. 2
). Sexual heterodonty weak; adult males with longer teeth and undeveloped lateral cusps on central portion of lower jaw. Upper teeth with slightly higher crowns than lower teeth, and with longer, stronger transverse ridges. Medial teeth and poorly differentiated symphysial teeth with higher crowns, and smaller than anteroposterior teeth, with erect or semi-erect cusps and one weak cusplet on either side of main cusp. Anteroposterior dentition in both jaws larger than medial teeth and symphysials, with semi-oblique cusps, and usually one strong high cusplet on either side. Gradient monognathic heterodonty well developed in anteroposterior teeth; anteroposteriors smaller distally, with thicker and more oblique cusps, and lower cusplets (
Fig. 12
). Sexual dimorphism of teeth described by
Gomes & TomÃ¡s ( 1991 )
.

. Scyliorhinus haeckelii
. A, B, C: UERJ 2233.9, female, 413 mm TL; D, E, F: UERJ 2209, adult male, 461 mm TL. A, D: region above pectoral fin; B, E: region below first dorsal fin; C, F: region below second dorsal fin.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Claspers short, slender and cylindrical, sometimes extending from free rear tips of pelvic fins (
Fig. 14
a); clasper inner length 1.1â1.4 times length of pelvic anterior margin (
Tab. 4
). Most of clasper covered by dermal denticles with anteriorly directed cusps, except apopyle (AP), hypopyle (HP), dorsomedial surface of glans, rhipidion (RH) and terminal dermal cover (TDC). Exorhipidion ( ERH ) well developed corresponding to 13.5â14 % of clasper inner length ( CLI ). Clasper hooks absent. Rhipidion well developed medially, covered by an anteriorly dilated cover rhipidion ( CRH ); insertion of rhipidion at anterior portion of accessory marginal dorsal cartilage (RD 2 ) (
Fig. 14
b). Cover rhipidion delimited anteriorly by a distinct envelope (EN), its length 10.9â11.2 % CLI (
Tab. 4
); in some specimens, cover rhipidion covers the medial portion of exorhipidion. Apopyle and hypopyle connected by a long clasper groove, with its dorsal margins fused over the clasper groove (CG). Pseudosiphon poorly developed and visualized only internally; pseudopera absent (
Fig. 15
). A terminal dermal cover present in the hindmost portion of clasper, covering one third of the ventral terminal cartilage and contacting exorhipidion and cover rhipidion.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 6 . Measurements of neurocrania in mm and as percentages of nasobasal length (% NL) for males and females of
S. haeckelii .
Abbreviation: n, number of specimens.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Measurements
Scyliorhinus haeckelii
Clasper skeleton relatively simple (
Fig. 16
a). Ventral marginal cartilage 25.6â27.2 % CLI ; dorsal marginal cartilage 31.3â32 % CLI (
Tab. 4
). A poorly developed accessory dorsal marginal cartilage present between the terminal portion of the dorsal marginal cartilage and anterior portion of the dorsal terminal (TD). Terminal portion of the clasper resembling a âknifeâ; dorsal terminal cartilage slightly shorter than ventral terminal (TV). Accessory terminal cartilage and dorsal terminal 2 cartilage absent. Ventral terminal 2 cartilage (TV 2 ) slender, positioned over the ventral terminal cartilage. Groove (GR) on terminal portion of ventral terminal cartilage absent or poorly developed (
Fig. 16
b). End-style (G) elongated and extending between terminal cartilages.

Scyliorhinus haeckelii

FIGURE 15. Detail of pseudosiphon (PSS), hypopyle (HP), and rhipidion (RH) in
Scyliorhinus haeckelii
(UERJ 1691, 522 mm TL). A: clasper glans region expanded; B: natural position of pseudosiphon indicated. Scale bar = 3 mm.

FIGURE 16. Clasper skeleton of
Scyliorhinus haeckelii
. A: entire clasper in dorsal view (UERJ 2233.6, male, 449 mm TL); B: detail of dorsolateral view of ventral terminal cartilage of same specimen as in A; C: detail of ventral and dorsal marginal cartilages and their associations to cartilages of the basal group (UERJ 1689, 566 mm TL). Abbreviations: AX, axial cartilage; Î², beta cartilage; b1, basal joint cartilage; G, end-style; GR, groove; RD, dorsal marginal cartilage; RD2, accessory dorsal marginal cartilage; RV, ventral marginal cartilage; TD, dorsal terminal cartilage; TV, ventral terminal cartilage; TV2, ventral terminal cartilage 2. Scale bar = 2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Caudal fin narrow-lobed and asymmetrical, with well-developed large terminal lobe ( Figs. 9 , 10 ). Caudal fin corresponding to 24 % of TL. Dorsal caudal lobe 2.2â2.7 times larger than the ventral lobe; subterminal caudal margin 0.5â1.1 times the terminal caudal margin. Dorsal caudal margin slightly convex, without lateral undulations. Denticles on caudal fin margins lacking crests.

Total vertebral counts 124 ( 117â127 ), monospondylous precaudal (MP) centra 38 ( 36â40 ). Transition between MP and diplospondylous (DP) centra posterior to pelvic bases and over clasper shafts. Last MP centrum before MPâDP transition smaller than the anterior MP centrum and larger than the first DP centrum, not forming a 'stutter zone' of alternating long and short centra.
Intestinal valve of conicospiral type , with 6 ( 6â8 ) turns.

Neurocranium broad and somewhat flattened, corresponding to 10 % TL (
Fig. 17
,
Tab. 6
). Rostral cartilages short and slender; rostral length 22.5â30 % of nasobasal length (NL). Distance between lateral rostral cartilages 12.7â18.3 % NL. Nasal capsules (NC) large, oval and expanded laterally; their width about equal to their length. Width across nasal capsules proportionately larger in males ( 73â79.1 % NL) compared to females ( 70â73.4 % NL). Nasal apertures (NA) broadly circular and laterally positioned on nasal capsules, 2 / 3 of their area covered by nasal fontanelle (NF). Width of nasal openings 22.2â27.2 % NL. Distance between rostral base and anterior edge of anterior fontanelle (AF) increasing with growth, reaching 45.8 % NL. Anterior fontanelle broad and subrectangular in males, and more heart-shaped in females, its width proportionally larger in females ( 22.5â24.5 % NL) compared to males ( 17.7â20.8 % NL). Basal plate (BP) flat and without keels, its width corresponding to 33.3â40.8 % NL. Orbits oval to subrectangular, their length 2.2 times in nasobasal length. Width across postorbital processes 1.2 times preorbital processes (PEP). Optic capsules short, their length 4.6 times in nasobasal length; their width 2.2â 2.5 times optic capsules length.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 17. Neurocranium of
Scyliorhinus haeckelii
. A: dorsal view (UERJ 1690, female, 467 mm TL); B: ventral view of specimen in A; C: dorsal view (UERJ 1689, male, 566 mm TL); D: ventral view of specimen in C. Abbreviations: AF, anterior fontanelle; ASC, anterior semicircular canal; CRF, cranial roof; FOE, external foramen of preorbital canal; FPE, external profundus foramen; HF, hyomandibular facet; ICF, internal carotid foramen; IS, internasal septum; LR, lateral rostral cartilage; MR, medial rostral cartilage; NA, nasal aperture; NC, nasal capsule; NF, nasal fontanelle; PEP, preorbital process; PRF, parietal fossa; PSC, posterior semicircular canal; PT, pterotic process; PTP, postorbital process; SC, supraorbital crest; SF, stapedial foramen; SG, supraorbital groove; SS, suborbital shelf. Scale bar = 1 cm.

FIGURE 18. Sexual dimorphism and ontogenetic changes in color pattern in
Scyliorhinus haeckelii
. A: females; B: males. All specimens adult except for smaller specimens at right in both A and B (all specimens from UERJ). Scale bar = 2 cm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Coloration . Color pattern with saddles darker than background color, not delineated by light or dark spots, and without sharp median projections; light and dark spots large and small, arranged in approximate bilateral symmetry, sometimes in intersaddle areas. Spots double, lunate or clear-centered, present on the back and sides. Lighter general color on ventral region. In most of cases, males more pigmented than females (
Fig. 18
). Adult males with white spots as of the post pectoral saddle (
Fig. 19
a), while in adult females, when present, as of the first dorsal fin saddle. Lunate spots larger and more frequent in males than in females; double spots more frequent in females (
Fig. 19
b). Juveniles smaller than 250 mm TL with little or no sexual dimorphism in color pattern.
